entry.title: Unlock What’s New: 2025 SAP Cloud ERP Private Release Deep Dive Series
entry.content:
Unlock What’s New: 2025 SAP Cloud ERP Private Release Deep Dive Series

The 2025 release of SAP Cloud ERP Private brings powerful innovations across every line of business with an AI-First, Suite-First strategy by integrating applications, data, and AI — from a strengthened core to embedded AI and intelligent agents that transform how work gets done.

You can join us December 8-11 in our exclusive deep-dive webinar series to discover how these new features provide tangible innovation impact across your key lines of business: 

  • Monday 8th Dec 4PM CET | 10AM EST- Overview of 2025 Cloud ERP Private Release Highlights, Procurement & Sales 
  • Tuesday 9th Dec 4PM CET | 10AM EST - Asset & Service Management
  • Wednesday 10th Dec 4PM CET | 10AM EST - Finance
  • Thursday 11th Dec 4PM CET | 10AM EST - Manufacturing, R&D and Supply Chain

This event is also open to partners.

 

 

Why should you attend?

In today’s fast-moving landscape, its important to stay up to date and adopt the innovations. In this series we will deep dive on the latest and greatest S/4HANA 2025 has to offer, so that you can plan your journey. We will cover:

Core Highlights:

  • Embedded AI: AI is integrated across key processes in your LoBs bringing precision and predictability to every decision.
  • Role-Aware Assistant: Joule is evolving into a role-aware assistant, tailoring insights and actions to each user’s responsibilities.
  • AI-Ready Data: Help businesses manage, analyze, and leverage their data with over 130 pre-delivered data products, accelerating decision-making.

LoB Highlights:

  • Finance: Achieve real-time profitability insight using universal parallel accounting and improve your cashflow with receivables and payables financing integrated with SAP Taulia. Improve liquidity with specialized agents like the Accounts Receivable Agent and shorten resolution cycle with the Dispute Management Agent.
  • Manufacturing & Supply Chain: Ensure faster, more reliable order fulfillment using the enhanced advanced available-to-promise (ATP) capability. Optimize warehouse operations with AI-assisted predictive labor demand planning.
  • Asset and Service: Improve equipment reliability and reduce downtime. The Maintenance Planner Agent recommends maintenance events and coordinates schedules based on interconnected data.
  • Procurement: Use Joule to simplify the creation of self-service purchase requisition and benefit from migration reports to transition to Lean Services.
  • Sales: Streamlines sales operations with AI-assisted sales order fulfillment and solution quotation creation. Explore how enhanced sales order and returns order management increase efficiency.
 
Additional Resources
  1. Blog Post: Should you wait until FPS1 is available before implementing or upgrading to SAP S/4HANA 2025?
  2. SAP News Center Article: Detailed insights in 2025 release "From Innovation to Impact: SAP Cloud ERP Private 2025 Release | SAP News Center”.
  3. SAP Community Posts: - List of publicly available content related to 2025 release 
  4. SAP.com Innovations Pages:
    • https://www.sap.com/products/erp/s4hana-private-edition.html#innovations 
    • https://www.sap.com/products/erp/s4hana-private-edition/innovations.html 

 

Register today to stay ahead with the latest innovations from SAP Cloud ERP Private.

For further information, please reach out to your SAP representative.

entry.title: SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – Foundational SAP Notes for SAP S/4HANA 2025
entry.content:
This blog post lists the main SAP Notes and software components for SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA 2025. 
This collection is provided as an aid to those customers installing or upgrading to SAP S/4HANA 2025 Cloud Private edition or SAP S/4HANA 2025 On-Premise.

Information is current for the initial shipment stack (ISS) of SAP S/4HANA 2025.

IMPORTANT: Many customers often ask whether they should wait for FPS1 before starting their SAP S/4HANA 2025 projects. To help clarify this, the SAP S/4HANA Regional Implementation Group (RIG) has published a dedicated blog:
Should you wait until FPS1 is available before implementing or upgrading to SAP S/4HANA 2025?

The blog explains that SAP S/4HANA 2025 FPS00 is a mature and stable release, already shipping with the long-term maintenance version SAPUI5 1.136, so customers can confidently begin their implementations from day one without waiting for FPS1.

You can find additional information on the major changes for SAP Fiori in SAP S/4HANA 2025 in blog posts:

    • SAP User Experience Update: What’s New for SAP S/4HANA 2025 (Private Cloud and On-Premise)

You can find additional information on the major changes for SAP Fiori Frontend Server in blog post:

    • SAP Fiori deployment options and SAP Fiori front-end server strategy - UPDATE 2025

IMPORTANT: Especially please note the statements in the above blog post around Strategy and future direction for SAP Fiori front-end server. Especially:

SAP Fiori front-end server 2025 for SAP S/4HANA (SAP FES 2025) :

  • has the same deployment recommendations as the predecessor versions (embedded or standalone FES server for SAP S/4HANA systems, hub deployment for Business Suite).
  • The end of maintenance of SAP FES 2025 is aligned with the maintenance period of SAP S/4HANA 2025. See also SAP note 3574267 - SAP Fiori front-end server 2025 for SAP S/4HANA.

You can find additional information on the major changes for the ABAP Platform in blog post:

    • ABAP Platform - major changes - COMING SOON!

Upgrading from a lower release of SAP S/4HANA:

  • Make sure you are aware of the major shifts in SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA. Refer to: SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – Upgrade Faster – Major shifts in SAP Fiori implementation

Planning to go Clean Core or use SAP Business AI with SAP S/4HANA 2025:

Refer to SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – Minimum UX you need for SAP Business AI and Clean Core

Major deprecations:

    • You can find more on which apps and UIs are deprecated in the What’s New Viewer for SAP S/4HANA by select Type = deleted, deprecated.
    • You can find major tool changes that are deleted or deprecated in the What's New Viewer for SAP S/4HANA by selecting Type = deprecated, must know deprecated
      • Please note the announcements re further deprecations of Launchpad Designer features

Important changes: 

    • 3383515 - From SAP_GWFND 758 version - OData V2 Services created will no longer require service specific ICF node for runtime operation

New apps for SAP S/4HANA 2025:

The new apps are already available in the SAP Fiori apps reference library.

Particularly useful new apps are:

  • F8438 Manage News
  • F7763 Cost Centers Review Booklet
  • F8226 HR Admin Processes 
  • F7651 Manage Payment Orders
  • and many new apps for MDG, Utilities, HCM for SAP S/4HANA, Group Reporting, Public Services, Transportation Management, and many more. 

There are also significant improvements in extending apps with Adapt UI including:

  • Adapt UI tour of the major features and options
  • What's New tour of Adapt UI 
  • New capabilities in changing table behaviors such as scrolling behaviour, text/id arrangements and many more. 

Hint: The library is regularly updated every couple of weeks with any changes.

SAP Help Documentation guides for SAP Fiori on SAP S/4HANA

SAP Fiori launchpad for SAP S/4HANA 2025

When using the What's New Viewer - SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition  filter on solution area ABAP Platform, valid as of release 2025, and look for solution capability SAP Fiori launchpad

Particularly useful new tools are:

  • Launchpad Content Aggregator for Roles now includes both content and layouts - refer to transaction /UI2/FLPCA
  • Launchpad Content Aggregator for User - refer to transaction /UI2/FLPCA_USER
  • You can set launchpad configuration parameters (client settings) for roles - refer to transaction /UI2/FLP_PROF_CONF
  • You can access an Administrator view of App Support, called the App Inspector.

IMPORTANT: Once you have installed or upgraded to SAP S/4HANA 2025, you should immediately check and patch up your minor versions for all UI technologies. That is you should patch up your minor versions for:

    • SAPUI5 version – for Fiori launchpad and SAP Fiori apps
    • Kernel version – for SAP GUI for HTML and SAP GUI for Windows
    • Unified Rendering version – for SAP GUI for HTML and ABAP Web Dynpro applications

Patching for SAP Fiori ( SAPUI5 )

Find the current minor patch levels at SAPUI5 Versions Maintenance Overview

You can find a short FAQ list on the patching process in SAP Note 2346367 – How to upgrade the SAPUI5 library in ABAP

The changes implemented by the patch are described in the UI5 Change Log – go to https://ui5.sap.com/#/releasenotes.html  and select release 1.136

Patching for Kernel

Find the current minor patch levels by checking the SAP Note 2083594 – SAP Kernel Versions and SAP Kernel Patch Levels . This includes the link to the latest patch note in the format: SAP Kernel <major version> Patch Level <patch level number>

For example:
3633957 - SAP Support Package Stack Kernel 9.16 PL 50 (RTC)

Patching for Unified Rendering

Find the current minor patch levels by checking the SAP Notes:

For Web Dynpro for ABAP –  SAP Note 2090746 - WD ABAP: Unified Rendering Update with TCI - Instructions and Related SAP Notes

Check the Solution section for your SAP_UI component version and the associate UR version and its SAP Note.

For SAP GUI for HTML – SAP Note 2504011 – SAP GUI for HTML: Unified Rendering Update – Instructions and Forecasts

You can find more information in SAP Note 2500800 – Cumulative patches for Unified Rendering

IMPORTANT:  You can also use the Upgrade Impact Analysis in the SAP Fiori apps reference library to plan for changes in apps and UIs. Find out how in Running an App Upgrade Impact Analysis.

Updating Rapid Activation and other tools

For Rapid Content Activation:

SAP Note 3608355 - Composite SAP note: Rapid Activation for SAP Fiori in SAP S/4HANA 2025

For SAP GUI for HTML (WebGUI):

Run transaction SITSPMON  and navigate to tab WebGUI Health Check

You’ll find much more on our  SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA topic page

entry.title: Streamline Your SAP Cloud ERP Private Upgrades with the New Release Upgrade Management Application
entry.content:
Upgrades are a critical part of keeping your SAP Cloud ERP Private environment secure, compliant, and ready for innovation. But coordinating them across complex system landscapes has traditionally required multiple tools, spreadsheets, and manual steps.

With SAP Cloud ERP Private Edition, SAP handles the technical side of your upgrades, applying standardized and proven methods for consistency and reliability.
Meanwhile, you and your implementation partner lead the planning and post-upgrade activities, ensuring everything runs seamlessly from preparation to go-live.

To make this process even easier, SAP now provides the Release Upgrade Management app — a centralized tool in SAP for Me that helps you plan, coordinate, and monitor your upgrade projects end-to-end.

 

Watch the Overview Video

Here’s a brief overview of how the Release Upgrade Management app helps you organize and manage your SAP Cloud ERP Private Edition upgrades. Watch the video. 

 

 

 

 

 

 

What Led Us to Create the Release Upgrade Management Application

Planning and executing an upgrade project require close coordination across your entire system landscape.

Historically, much of this coordination happened through spreadsheets, emails, or manual processes. The Release Upgrade Management Application changes that.

The tool was developed by SAP Enterprise Cloud Services (ECS) to make upgrade planning transparent, structured, and collaborative — allowing customers, partners, and SAP teams to work together in one place. With it, you can map out your upgrade across your entire landscape, see how everything is connected, and prepare the work without running into unexpected issues. It also helps you estimate the time and resources to keep your productive environment stable until the scheduled downtime.

The goal is to make upgrades more predictable, less stressful and easier to manage. 

 

How Release Upgrade Management Helps You

After logging in via SAP for Me > Services & Support > Private Cloud Workspace > Release Upgrade Management, you can:

  • Set up an upgrade project , define the scope and target release, connected agents, and system landscape
  • Identify the optimal upgrade path using built-in best practices and dependency analysis for OS, DB, and application versions
  • Generate an upgrade timeline automatically that you can adapt to match your internal planning cycle. 
  • Track and manage tasks across all phases — discovery, planning, preparation, execution, and review — with clear responsibilities for SAP and customer teams
  • Collaborate in one shared workspace for customers, partners and SAP using notes, attachments, and comments to stay aligned at every stage.
  • Leverage insights from past projects to reuse templates and and make future upgrades easier to plan.

 

Explore the Guided Demo

See a walkthrough of how to set up, plan, and track an upgrade project in SAP for Me. Watch the demo video. 

 



 

 

Two Versions, Depending on Your Needs

Release Upgrade Management is available in two editions:

  • Basic Version: Included for all SAP Enterprise Cloud Services customers, covering the essential planning and monitoring features.
  • Enhanced Operations Version: Available for customers with the enhanced operations service for managed upgrades and updates package, which includes dedicated SAP project management and Basis consulting support.

Both versions provide the same intuitive, self-service access — the difference lies in how SAP supports the execution. Learn more here.

 

Get Started

You can access the Release Upgrade Management application via SAP for Me → Service & Support → Private Cloud Workspace → Release Upgrade Management.

Resources and Support:

  • Read SAP Note 3372118 for the latest information and user guide
  • For questions and feedback contact the Release Upgrade Management product team at SAP_ECS_RUM_tool@sap.com
  • Report issues via this technical support component in SAP For Me: XX-SER-FORME-ECS-RUM

Limitation

The Release Upgrade Management application is available for all SAP Enterprise Cloud Services customers (delivered by SAP Enterprise Cloud Services).

If you're working through upcoming upgrades, the Release Upgrade Management application may help you organize the tasks and see the overall plan more clearly. Feedback from the community will continue to shape how the tool evolves.

entry.title: Product Inspiration Series - Experience a new Era of SAP CX (wave #5)
entry.content:
Hi everyone, on behalf of the CX Product Success team I am delighted to share with you our latest deep dive videos as part of the SAP Product Inspiration Series 2025 for CX. 

Wave  #5 (Nov/Dec 2025)

 

1. Essity's Business Transformation with SAP Customer Experience

Join Denise Bender (User Experience Design Manager for CX at SAP) in an inspiring discussion with Daniele Tedesco (eCommerce Global Process Owner at Essity) about the CX Transformation at Essity. Watch this customer-led product inspiration video to dive into topics such as Essity's choice of SAP CX for their digital transformation, the specific SAP CX solutions implemented, how Essity supports both B2B and B2C customers in one integrated system, upcoming CX journey milestones, key lessons learned, and an interactive demo showcasing Essity's enhanced B2B portal. The demo highlights intuitive search capabilities, modernized navigation, and a secure shopping experience, all driven by SAP Commerce Cloud. This video provides valuable insights into Essity's strategy for creating a seamless and efficient customer experience.

The key highlights shared in this video are:
00:00 - Introduction
01:05 - Why did Essity choose SAP CX for digital transformation?
01:55 - Which SAP CX solutions have been implemented?
03:23 - How does Essity support B2B and B2C in one system?
06:23 - What’s next on your CX journey at Essity?
07:51 - What were some of the lessons you have learnt in terms of SAP CX?
09:06 - Start of the Demo
09:20 - Demo: Interactive and engaging B2B Portal based on SAP Commerce Cloud
09:58 - Demo: Easy to navigate categories and products
10:45 - Demo: Intuitive and comprehensive search capabilities
11:44 - Demo: Modernized cart experience and safe checkout process
13:04 - Summary: Intelligent CX from SAP

 

2. ERCO's Business Transformation with SAP Sales Cloud Version 2, SAP Emarsys and SAP Business AI

Join Barbara Holzmeister (Senior Customer Success Manager at SAP) in an inspiring discussion with Oliver Heid (CIO at ERCO) and Florian Mages (Teamlead SAP CX at Adesso) about the implementation of SAP Sales Cloud Version 2, SAP Emarsys, and AI scenarios at ERCO. Watch this customer-led product inspiration video to learn how ERCO leverages key innovative solutions to optimize customer relationships and drive customer satisfaction. Discover the key benefits and positive impacts these tools have had on ERCO’s business operations, making their journey a role model for successful transformations in the area or B2B sales and account based marketing.

The key highlights shared in this video are:
00:00 - Introduction
00:23 - Why has ERCO embarked on a digital transformation journey with SAP Customer Experience?
03:41 - What specific scenarios have been implemented at ERCO?
04:57 - Which SAP Business AI functions are you using today and how satisfied are you with the outcome of the project?
05:57 - Which advice would you give to other companies who’re just starting their SAP CX journey?
07:04 - What are your favorite features of SAP CX?
08:21 - Any final thoughts from Adesso regarding the partner approach at ERCO?
09:16 - Start of the Demo
09:43 - Demo: Task Manager in SAP Sales Cloud Version 2
10:18 - Demo: Pipeline Manager
11:21 - Demo: Forecast Tracker
12:07 - Demo: Pipeline Flow
12:52 - Summary: Intelligent CX from SAP

 

3. Döhler: Bringing Ideas to Life with Intelligent CX across SAP Business Suite 

Join Nina Springstubbe (Program Manager Cross Product Experience & Innovation at SAP) in an inspiring discussion with Michelle Emmerich (Teamlead Sales Excellence at Döhler) and Rasim Özkan (Manager SAP CX at Solvia) about Intelligent CX across SAP Business Suite at Döhler. Watch this customer-led product inspiration video to discover why Döhler chose SAP CX and how it fits their strategy. Learn about the specific SAP CX solutions that have been implemented at Döhler. Hear about Döhler’s satisfaction with SAP CX and the business value it delivers at Döhler. See an exclusive demo covering Döhler’s WE|LEAD processes in SAP Sales & Service Cloud Version 2 incl. KPI cards, global search functionality, account details, overall account timeline, Account 360 through embedded SAP Analytics Cloud, embedded B2B account data from SAP S/4HANA, and the Custom AI Account Development Plan while leveraging seamless integration to SAP S/4HANA backend processes.

The key highlights shared in this video are:
00:00 - Introduction
00:23 - Why did Döhler choose SAP CX?
01:07 - Which specific solutions have been implemented at Döhler?
02:04 - How satisfied is Döhler with SAP CX?
02:18 - What’s your favorite feature of SAP CX?
05:09 - What advice would you give other customers?

4. Döhler: Streamlined Sales Processes through Guided Selling in SAP Sales Cloud Version 2

Join Christian Guenther (Customer Success Manager CX at SAP) in an inspiring discussion with Michelle Emmerich (Teamlead Sales Excellence at Döhler) and Rasim Özkan (Manager SAP CX at Solvia) about Streamlined Sales Processes Through Guided Selling in SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 at Döhler. Watch this customer-led product inspiration video to discover why Döhler chose Guided Selling in SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 and how it fits their strategy. Learn about the specific Guided Selling capabilities that have been implemented and hear about the business value that Guided Selling has delivered for Döhler. Get advice from Döhler on how other companies can benefit from Guided Selling in SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 and watch an exclusive step-by-step demo about Guided Selling and Activity Playbooks from Lead to Opportunity at Döhler.

entry.title: Struggling with GR/IR Differences during Invoice posts? Use the Invoice Posting Analysis report
entry.content:
Hey All,
 
Handling GR/IR (WRX) issues can be challenging, especially when unexpected balances appear after posting logistics invoice verification documents.
 
As someone who works closely with global support teams and customer scenarios, I see the same pattern: customers spend significant time trying to understand how SAP calculated the WRX (GR/IR clearing) amount.

 

The good news?
SAP provides a helpful analysis tool that is still not widely known:
👉 Invoice Posting Analysis report: IV_WRX_ANALYSIS
 
This report is described in SAP Note 2427297 - Analysis report to explain GR/IR amount (WRX line item), and in this blog, I want to make it simple, visual, and practical, so more customers can use it with confidence.



What the Invoice Posting Analysis Report Does
 
The Invoice Posting Analysis report (IV_WRX_ANALYSIS) explains how the system calculated the amount posted to the GR/IR clearing account (transaction key WRX) during Logistics Invoice Verification.
 
It explains the logic for material and planned delivery costs items. The document types that can be analyzed are:
- Invoices
- Credit memos
- Subsequent debits
- Subsequent credits
- Account maintenance documents including documents with multiple account assignment
 
This makes it an extremely valuable tool when:
- You see a difference between the goods receipt and the invoice
- The WRX amount is not what you expected
- The invoice hits unexpected accounts
- You need to explain the calculation to business users or auditors



What the Report Does Not Cover
 
To set the right expectations, the report does not explain calculations for:
- Unplanned delivery cost
- Taxes in the WRX line
- Foreign currencies
- Account maintenance documents for account-assigned purchase orders
- Contract invoices
- Direct postings to material or G/L accounts
- It also does not explain the amounts calculated for price difference (PRD/KBS) or exchange rate difference (KDM) postings
 
If your case falls into one of these categories, you may still need a deeper analysis.
 
 
How to Implement the Report (Manual Installation)
 
Because Note 2427297 does not contain SNOTE correction instructions, the report must be implemented manually.

 

✔️Steps to Implement:
1. Go to transaction SE38 or SE80.
2. Create the following includes exactly with these names:
- IV_WRX_ANALYSIS
- IV_WRX_ANALYSIS_TOP
3. Copy the source code from the attachments in Note 2427297 into the respective includes.
4. Activate both includes.

 

🔔Tip:
If you have already implemented an older version of the report, simply replace the existing code with the latest version from the Note.
 
Once activated, you can run the report IV_WRX_ANALYSIS using the SE38 transaction.
 
 
How to Run and Use the Report
 
1️⃣ Execute the Report
Go to transaction SE38 → enter IV_WRX_ANALYSIS → Execute.
 
2️⃣Enter the Selection Criteria
You only need three inputs:
- Document Number
- Fiscal Year
- Document Item
 
 
This makes it quick and simple to use, even during high-pressure situations like month-end closing.
 
3️⃣Analyze the Output
The report displays three clear sections:
 
A) Invoice & PO Details
All relevant information the system considered for the calculation, such as:
- PO details: Net Value, Net Price, Quantity
- Invoice and Goods Receipt details (depending on the formula used and the scenario)
 
B) Calculation Logic
This is the heart of the report.
It shows:
- The formula used by the system
- All values used in the calculation (GR quantities, invoice amounts, and condition values for each account)
- The final calculated WRX (GR/IR) amount
 
This transparency makes it much easier to verify whether the calculated value is correct.
 
Important Note: You will see the calculated value of the GR/IR (WRX) clearing account posted during the Invoice Receipt process.
 
C) Documentation
A helpful reference section with links to related information.
 

Image/data in this blog is from SAP internal systems, sample data, or demo systems. Any resemblance to real data is purely coincidental.

Why You Should Use This Report
 
The Invoice Posting Analysis report is one of the most effective tools for:
- Understanding complex WRX postings
- Reducing investigation time during closing
- Preparing clear explanations for business users, auditors, or finance teams
- Preventing unnecessary support cases
 
Still, many customers are not aware that this report exists, which is why I wanted to bring visibility to it!



Final Recommendation
 
If you work with Invoice Verification, other Procurement areas, or Finance, I highly encourage you to:
✔️Implement the report manually (it only takes a few minutes)
✔️Use it for each case where WRX amounts look unexpected
✔️Share the Note 2427297 with your internal teams
✔️Attach the report output when creating SAP Support cases
 
It will save you time, prevent misunderstandings, and bring full clarity to your GR/IR calculations.
 
If you have questions, need help implementing the report, or want to share feedback, feel free to leave a comment below.
 
It was nice to connect with you again 😉
 
Best regards,
Carla Bussolo

entry.title: The value of SAP Business Data Cloud for SAP Cloud ERP Private
entry.content:
• SAP Business Data Cloud (SAP BDC) for SAP Cloud ERP Private
  • What is different now? What value and which other new aspects is SAP BDC to our customer?
  • How is the solution positioned?
  • From SAP BW to SAP BDC: what’s really different
  • Working with Databricks and other partners
  • AI in and with SAP BDC
  • Intelligent applications: what they are and why they matter
  • The business case: value that compounds
  • Commercial packaging: how to get the solution
  • What’s next?

SAP Business Data Cloud (SAP BDC) for SAP Cloud ERP Private

The Unified Data Foundation for SAP Business Suite and beyond
Enabling Seamless Integration, Analytics & AI-Driven Processes

What is different now? What value and which other new aspects is SAP BDC to our customer?

Bringing AI, data and apps together: How Business Data Cloud supercharges SAP Cloud ERP Private

If there’s one theme you’ve heard from recent keynotes, it’s this: the future of enterprise performance lies in bringing AI, data and applications together. When you do, you unlock a flywheel of value. Better data fuels better AI. Better AI augments apps and decisions. Better (configured) apps generate richer data. Round and round it goes, compounding benefit.

Why this matters: three layers that work as one can support a new dimension of productivity and decision support!

Think about the stack in three reinforcing layers:

 

1. Applications and data sources

  • SAP applications anchor your critical processes and transactional truth.
  • Non-SAP data also matters: external signals, benchmark data, industry specific and market data, documents, logs, time series and more. This includes data sources with structured and unstructured data.
  • Partnerships and integrations with other data bases expand your reach so you can meet the data where it lives.

2. A harmonized enterprise data foundation

  • Business Data Cloud provides a harmonized semantic layer, delivered in a SaaS application, across all lines of business, applications and applicable to all industries.
  • Prebuilt and curated data products turn raw sources into ready-to-run, semantically consistent building blocks you can trust.
  • The result is a complete enterprise view that supports scenario modeling, planning and cross-process insight without the heavy lifting of manual integration

3. Business AI and modern experiences

  • Agents and assistants like Joule bring an intuitive, conversational layer to analytics and processes.
  • Embedded, real-time insights blend directly into workflows, so users get guidance where decisions happen.
  • Agentic AI will cross systems and processes; it relies on a consistent, governed data foundation, across systems, models and data structures, to be executable and hereby safe and useful.

 

How is the solution positioned?

It is a fact that every customer has a different situation from which they look at this innovation. So everyone needs to be picked up where they come from. When you frame BDC with Cloud ERP Private and AI, it seems best to point out these facts:

  • Considering an end-to-end data lifecycle across SAP and non-SAP is key: SAP customers already have investments in platforms like Databricks, Snowflake and SAP HANA Cloud. Following the idea to unify ingestion, harmonization, governance, enrichment and consumption so analytics, planning and AI all helps everyone to run on consistent ground truth.
  • Debating BW modernization and moving to BDC is worth the time: Many customers are  live with BW on-premise plus a patchwork of analytics. To modernize to a cloud-native, governed data foundation with prebuilt data products, and leave behind the complexity and costs of stitching systems on your own, may help a lot of these organizations and companies.
  • Focusing on adopting intelligent apps: Turn on high-value, out-of-the-box insights and decision support can align to specific line-of-business or industry pain points, and show quick wins that compound over time.

From SAP BW to SAP BDC: what’s really different

 

SAP BW has been a foundational analytics technology for decades. But BDC is not a one-for-one replacement—it’s a bigger step forward because:

  • It’s SaaS. SAP BDC is delivered as a cloud service. SAP takes responsibility for provisioning, maintaining structures and deploying the data products, so customers can start with usable content rather than building from scratch.
  • It’s a unified business data fabric. SAP BDC harmonizes data from multiple SAP and non-SAP sources, preserving business context and the underlying data models. That context in particular matters. It enables consistent semantics across systems and allows values to potentially flow back into SAP ERP where appropriate—an advantage only SAP can deliver at this depth. The data is capable to also serve for a root to understand the sentiment needed for business decisions.
  • It’s built for agentic AI. Agent networks span processes and systems, and they must rely on a consistent, governed data layer. SAP BDC is where those harmonization rules and transformations live, not just in point-to-point API orchestrations.
  • It extends embedded analytics. The models used in embedded analytics and SAP Analytics Cloud can directly fuel BDC data products. This way, you get continuity of semantics from source to insight.

Working with Databricks and other partners

A common misconception is that opening up to non-SAP platforms means giving up control. The reality is more nuanced:

  • It’s bi-directional and fair. If Databricks is the customers’ data lakehouse of choice, SAP BDC can read from it (then named SAP Databricks)—and Databricks can read from SAP systems governed by your connectivity and security policies.
  • Customers keep their investments. You can bring existing data, models and know-how forward and integrate them into SAP BDC-powered use cases.
  • SAP’s value is context. What differentiates SAP BDC is its ability to bring data in with full business semantics, align it with SAP data models, and enable value to flow back to the SAP ERP processes. No one else can do that as deeply.

AI in and with SAP BDC

AI shows up in multiple ways:

  • AI powered by SAP BDC. With clean, governed, harmonized data products, you can trust the models and agents you deploy. This is where you’ll use Joule, Just Ask in SAP Analytics Cloud, smart functions, embedded insights or fuel any SAP Business AI-enabled processes.
  • AI to build SAP BDC. Within Datasphere, AI and knowledge graph capabilities help optimize data modeling, Apply data science and AI to enrich data products by deriving attributes, harmonizing time series and more. SAP is investing in foundation models tailored for enterprise data contexts to improve derivations and semantics. Agentsmay help in creating analytical artefacts, such as stories. Also Ai is embedded in core analytics functions such as Just Ask, Smart functions ans will be available for generic services, such as summarizations, or the interpretation of results. Finally, Joule is planned as new UI for the analytics environment.

The net: you’re not just using AI at the “last mile.” You’re using it to build a better first mile too.

Intelligent applications: what they are and why they matter

Intelligent applications are not just apps in the narrow sense. Think of them as packaged, outcome-driven solutions composed of:

  • SAP curated data products. Primary and derived data products that harmonize and transform source data, including ready-made KPIs and calculations, where the second layer is a clear gain compared to what was there initially in Datasphere.
  • Domain content. Prebuilt SAP Analytics Cloud stories or other low or no-code assets that deliver immediate analytical value.
  • Applications. Where needed, deeper BTP applications (for example, CAP/RAP) that orchestrate complex decision support across processes.

 

Schematic visualization of Intelligent Applications, Applications, Insights and underlying Data Products, suggested content except marked (e)xtisting or (p)lanned, focus on SAP Cloud ERP Intelligence Private:

Examples:

  • Working Capital Insights. An established SAP Analytics Cloud story, now embedded in the SAP BDC data product concept to help finance teams optimize cash, DSO/DPO and working capital levers.
  • Sustainability Control Tower. A CAP-based application which is getting aligned with SAP BDC data products, bringing ESG and operational data together for visibility and action.

Strategically, SAP is prioritizing industry-focused applications where standardizable decision support exists beyond finance—areas where uncertainty, external signals and cross-LOB collaboration make a consistent data and AI foundation indispensable. One target will be to create a decision support control center, where it should be possible to pre-evaluate insights showing the as-is situation, and possible reaction scenarios can get generated, developed and finally have a fit in the execution in the underlying systems and their operational processes. Besides this, other pro-code applications with LoB focus are planned.

The business case: value that compounds

Three concrete value pillars typically drive the ROI story:

  • Reduce data engineering effort. Prebuilt, ready-to-run data products can remove up to 80% of the data acquisition and curation effort for many scenarios, especially for customers who previously hand-assembled data pipelines and models around BW.
  • Increase trust and speed with harmonization. Cross-system alignment is costly to build and fragile to maintain in bespoke setups. BDC provides consistent semantics out of the box, so teams can move faster from data to insight to action with fewer errors and reconciliations.
  • Expanded business impact with Insights to Action through intelligent app. Out-of-the-box analytics, planning and decision support reduce time-to-value. Teams get a head start and can tailor from there.

SAP value engineering provides a framework and tooling to quantify total benefits (as a percentage of operating profit and in absolute terms), against costs. Expect modeling around net present value, ROI, payback period and internal rate of return, grounded in customer-specific inputs and scenarios. Happy to discuss in concrete customer interactions.

Of course, there is more value in this setup than to cccelerate analytics or planning, based on delivered Intelligent Applications. In addition, you can make use of SAP Business AI on SAP BDC data, incl. AI Agents/-networks. SAP BDC is the strategic data layer for all SAP Business AI applications, where you can Build own Business AI for the SAP context of your organization, while assuring data consistency, harmonization across SAP Suite products and other API-connected non SAP systems.

Commercial packaging: how to get the solution

At a high level, the packaging aligns the platform and the outcomes:

  • First prerequisite is of course SAP Cloud ERP Private (regular, base or tailored options).
  • Second is the Intelligent application. SAP Cloud ERP Intelligence Private covers access to the intelligent application content itself (data products, domain content, and where applicable, application components).
  • To facilitate the Solution, it is necessary to also have Core SAP BDC capacities linked with it, based on expected size and activity in the system.

 

Be aware that there are also trials available to help teams explore and de-risk.

SAP teams can help shape the right configuration and necessary sizes.

How to get started

  • Pick a high-impact use case. Working capital, sustainability and finance insights are proven entry points. They showcase value quickly and build organizational momentum.
  • Make an inventory of the existing data landscape. Identify SAP and non-SAP sources that matter for the use case. Note where Databricks, Snowflake or other platforms already hold valuable data or models or may add additional value.
  • Assess your SAP BW footprint. If you’re on SAP BW on-premise, map a modernization path to SAP BDC/ Datasphere. Reuse skills and assets where possible.
  • Pilot with purpose. Use trials and prebuilt content to deliver a credible early win, then scale by extending data products and domain content.
  • Plan for AI enablement. Design for agentic AI from day one by leveraging SAP BDC’s harmonized semantics. Embed insights where decisions happen, and use Joule and Just Ask to bring analytics to life for users.

What’s next?

 

The content set is growing:

  • Hundreds of data packages are being delivered and extended across lines of business and industries.
  • More apps and visualizations will arrive with increasing industry depth.
  • The integration of SAP’s AI assistant and agentic capabilities will deepen across SAP BDC and SAP Cloud ERP Private.

The bottom line

  • This is not old wine in a new bottle. Business Data Cloud with SAP Cloud ERP Private is a new, SaaS-native foundation that unifies data, accelerates trusted insight and enables AI to actually work across the applying enterprise.
  • It’s unique in its depth of business context. Only SAP can harmonize SAP and non-SAP data with the semantics and process awareness needed to feed insights back into ERP workflows safely and effectively.
  • It meets the customers where they are. Keeping their investments in Databricks, Snowflake and other platforms. Using them alongside SAP BDC to enrich and extend.
  • It’s outcome-oriented. Intelligent applications give our customers a head start on real decisions, not just dashboards.
  • It’s measurable. With prebuilt data products reducing engineering effort and intelligent apps accelerating adoption, an organization’s ROI can be calculated with a clear line to operating performance.

If you’re ready to turn “AI + data + apps” from a slogan into a system, start with a use case, lean on SAP BDC’s prebuilt content, and let the flywheel turn. The sooner to harmonize the data and semantics, the faster analytics, planning and agentic AI will compound value across our customers enterprises and organizations.

entry.title: BP user exits to check data before saving (SAP GUI transaction for Business Partners)
entry.content:
I've read a few questions and answers about which user exit to choose to add custom checks before saving in the SAP GUI transaction BP (maintenance of business partners), but without understanding which ones to choose, how they are all related, what they exactly do. I'm trying here to provide an overview of what I have quickly understood.

I'm running S/4HANA 2023 FPS 1 (ABAP 7.58 SP 1).

In short, there are these user exits, called sequentially:

  • the BP checks by the BDT framework (Business Data Toolset),
  • the BP checks by the BAdI BUPA_FURTHER_CHECKS,
  • the vendor or customer specific checks by the BAdI VENDOR_EXTENSION_CHECK and CUSTOMER_EXTENSION_CHECK.
  • NB: if I understand well, S/4HANA has merged customer and vendor maintenance into BP, and before S/4HANA, there were specific vendor and customer user exits (not part of BP) which were the Business Transaction Events 1340 and 1440 and the BAdI CUSTOMER_ADD_DATA and VENDOR_ADD_DATA, method CHECK_ALL_DATA. I don't discuss them here.

In BP, the BDT checks are first called. You may create your own function module (no parameters) and add it to the transaction code BUS7 for the event DCHCK. For the sequence number, you may enter any two last characters (positions 6 and 7) other than "00" (double zero), because the positions are reserved for custom use, as explained in the SAP Help Portal:

  • Naming convention: The position number has 7 places. Each development stage has one place of its own. The places from the left up to your own place are freely assignable. The application uses them to determine the position of the view within a section in relation to the views of the upstream development stages. The numbers to the right of your own place must be ‘0’.
  • The following places are reserved for the development stages:
  • Application basis 1+2
  • Standard applications 3
  • Industry applications 4
  • Development partners 5
  • Customers (central) 6
  • Customers (branch) 7

Then, the method CHECK_CENTRAL of the Classic BAdI BUPA_FURTHER_CHECKS is called. You may also implement it (transaction code SE18, menu Implementations > Create). This method receives few parameters (table BUT000, name, organization data, person data). If you need other data from the business partner, you may call function modules like BUP_BUPA_BUT0IS_GET (table BUT0IS being the industry sectors defined at the BP level) to get the data modified (or not) by the user, before the data is really saved to the database.

After that, if the partner is of type vendor, BP calls the method CHECK of the BAdI Definition VENDOR_EXTENSION_CHECK of the Enhancement Spot VENDOR_EXTENSION.

If the partner of type customer, BP calls the method CHECK of the BAdI Definition CUSTOMER_EXTENSION_CHECK of the Enhancement Spot CUSTOMER_EXTENSION.

The two BAdI above receive only the vendor or customer specific data, not the whole business partner data, to prevent saving the data to the vendor or customer specific tables LFA1, KNA1 (and so on), but even if an error is raised by the user exit, the business partner data is saved.

In my case, I wanted to define a blocking check on BP data, the most simple way, so I used the classic BAdI BUPA_FURTHER_CHECKS.

For information, if you want to know about how the vendor or customer specific data is filtered out from the business partner data, it's done by the class CVI_STRATEGY_BP_VENDOR, in the method IF_MDS_CTRL_STRATEGY_IMPL~PROCESS.

I don't know how exactly the BP customizing decides how to display the vendor or customer data, and how it's saved into the tables LFA1, KNA1, etc. What I could understand:

  1. If you create a Business Partner, you choose a partner group from the table TB000 (e.g. PCUS, PVEN)
  2. The SPRO activity "Define partner role from client to partner" (SM30 > CVIV_CUST_TO_BP2) assigns one or more partner roles (e.g. FLCU00) to the partner group (e.g. PCUS).
  3. The SPRO activity "Define partner role from vendor to partner" (SM30 > CVIV_VEND_TO_BP2) assigns one or more partner roles (e.g. FLVN00) to a partner group (e.g. PVEN).
  4. The SPRO activity "Define partner roles" (SM34 > BUPA_TB003) links the partner role (e.g. FLCU00) to the BDT partner view (e.g. FLCU00). This BDT partner view is defined in the transaction BUSD and is connected to Dynpro screens with ABAP logic. It's not clear to me how, from here, some BDT partner function modules are called at save time and how they write to either the table LFA1 (vendor) or KNA1 (customer).
  5. The SPRO activity "Assign partner role to client group" (V_TBD001) assigns a client group from KNA1-KTOKD (e.g. CUST) to a partner group (e.g. PCUS). This customizing indicates if the client number is the same as the partner number. For information, the relationship table is CVI_CUST_LINK.
  6. The SPRO activity "Assign partner role to vendor group" (V_TBC001) assigns a vendor group from LFA1-KTOKK (e.g. VEND) to a partner group (e.g. PVEN). This customizing indicates if the vendor number is the same as the partner number. For information, the relationship table is CVI_VEND_LINK.

If I've missed something, if I'm wrong or if you can enlighten me, please add a comment. I will then update this post.

Thank you for reading!

entry.title: How to Validate an S/4HANA Business Case During the Discover Phase: A PM’s Real Checklist
entry.content:
When we start an S/4HANA project, the business case is usually the first document everyone refers to. In reality, the business case is often created long before the full project team arrives — sometimes by a pre-sales team, sometimes by IT leadership, and sometimes by business leaders who describe goals in very high-level terms.

In my current S/4HANA program in Saudi Arabia for a Food & Beverages customer, the Discover phase exposed several gaps that forced us to rethink the original business case. I’ve learned that this phase isn’t just a formality — it’s where we find out whether the transformation objectives are real or just assumptions.

Below is a practical checklist I use as a PM during Discover to validate the business case before stepping into Prepare.

1. Understand the Real Drivers

In one of our meetings, the stakeholders described goals like “modernizing operations” and “improving reporting.” These are nice words, but they don’t help a project team make decisions.

When I pushed for concrete definitions, we discovered:

  • Some departments wanted S/4HANA mainly for analytics
  • Others wanted automation
  • Some just wanted to fix ongoing ECC issues

Until you understand why the business truly wants S/4HANA — beyond the fancy terminology — the project will struggle with alignment later.

2. Confirm Whether the “Right” Stakeholders Are Even in the Room

This is something I’ve seen repeatedly, especially in the Middle East region.

During the Discover workshops:

  • A department head would join for the first meeting
  • Then send a junior team member from the second meeting
  • Who was not authorized to make decisions

In one case, we realized the actual process owner from Production Planning wasn’t even involved. This led to misunderstandings and rework.

A realistic business case depends on real decision-makers being identified early.

3. Validate Whether Expected Scope Matches Real Needs

One of my personal beliefs in S/4HANA projects is that scope definition makes or breaks the program.

In our project, the initial scope mentioned only core modules. But after high-level discussions, it became clear that:

  • Treasury Management (TRM)
  • Multi-Bank Connectivity (MBC)
  • IBP (for demand planning)

None of these were reflected in the original budget or timelines.

Discover Phase is the right time to:

  • Validate processes
  • Identify missing modules
  • Check whether additional components are actually necessary

This prevents surprises later.

4. Recheck Cost Assumptions — Especially Cloud & Licensing

A very real situation we faced:
The cloud subscription cost was significantly underestimated in the business case.

Once we confirmed:

  • Required number of Fiori users
  • Additional modules
  • Integration add-ons

…the budget increased noticeably.

Licensing and cloud costs must be validated with:

  • SAP
  • The cloud provider
  • Integration and automation tools

If not corrected in Discover, these gaps snowball later.

5. Validate Organizational Readiness (Especially SME Availability)

I strongly believe that SME availability is one of the biggest success factors.

In our project:

  • Some SMEs were handling daily operations
  • Some had never worked on SAP before
  • A few didn’t understand what S/4HANA changes would mean

This directly impacts timelines, testing effort, and even the design.

If SME bandwidth is limited, the business case’s timeline assumptions must change.

6. Assess Integration and Data Reality Against Assumptions

In our case, the business case assumed:

  • “Minimal integrations”
  • “Data is mostly clean”

Both turned out to be incorrect.

Reality:

  • Several factory systems required real-time integration
  • Historical data archiving was never done
  • Some modules had inconsistent master data ownership

You cannot rely on assumptions made during a sales cycle.
Discover Phase is the moment to validate the actual landscape.

Final Thoughts

The Discover Phase is where the business case either strengthens or collapses.
From my experience managing SAP programs in the Middle East region, the biggest issues in Discover are usually:

  • unclear goals,
  • missing stakeholders,
  • underestimated licensing,
  • additional modules required, and
  • conflicts between departments.

A PM’s job in Discover is not just to review the business case — it’s to challenge it, validate it, and correct it based on real conversations and real system realities.

A well-validated business case saves months of pain later.

entry.title: The Next Level of Global Payments: SAP Unlocks Enhanced Cross-Border Capabilities with TransferMate
entry.content:
In an increasingly interconnected global economy, businesses need payment solutions that are fast, transparent, secure, and seamlessly integrated into their ERP systems. That’s why the newly announced partnership between SAP and TransferMate represents a major step forward for finance and treasury teams.

Through this partnership, TransferMate’s cross-border payment service is now integrated directly into SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity as a non-bank payments provider bringing powerful and innovative global payment capabilities straight into SAP ERP solutions, including SAP Cloud ERP.

For organizations operating across multiple currencies and jurisdictions, this integration has the potential to significantly simplify international financial operations.

Traditionally, making international payments required organizations to juggle multiple banking partners, external platforms, or third-party portals. This fragmented processes introduced friction, increased operational risk, and added unnecessary costs that this partnership can solve

What You Can Expect from TransferMate’s integration into SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity

- Fast, transparent and efficient international payments without leaving your ERP

  • No additional portals or manual steps; enjoy seamless straight-through processing.
  • Automated flows from SAP ERP directly to TransferMate payment infrastructure reducing errors, manual intervention, and operational risk.

- Reduced complexity and improved scalability

  • SAP users can send and receive funds globally through a the unified and standardized payment infrastructure from TransferMate.
  • A scalable payment solution that grows with organizations expanding their international footprint.

- Greater transparency and control

  • End-to-end visibility from cross border payment initiation to settlement
  • Enhanced liquidity management with better payment tracking and more payment options.

- Strengthened compliance and security

  • TransferMate operates a fully regulated global payments network, ensuring adherence to local and international financial regulations.

Who Can Benefit?

Any organization using SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity—regardless of whether they are running SAP ERP, SAP S/4HANA, or SAP Cloud ERP—can take advantage of this integration.

As companies continue to expand globally, the demand for frictionless, embedded financial tools will only grow. The integration of TransferMate into SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity marks a major step toward making global payments as simple, secure, and seamless as domestic transactions—directly from your SAP environment.

Want to Know More?

SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity

  • https://www.sap.com/germany/products/financial-management/multi-bank-connectivity.html
  • https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_MULTI_BANK_CONNECTIVITY

TransferMate

  • https://www.transfermate.com/
  • TransferMate Press Release

entry.title: How to Assign Item Category to Material While Syncing to SAP CPQ – And Why It Matters
entry.content:
When integrating SAP CPQ (Configure, Price, Quote) with SAP S/4HANA or ERP, ECC, one critical step often overlooked is assigning the Item Category to materials during synchronization. This seemingly small detail plays a major role in ensuring smooth downstream processes like Sales Orders, Solution Quotations, and Solution Orders.

What is an Item Category ?

An Item Category in SAP determines how a material behaves in a document. It controls:

  • Whether the item is relevant for pricing.
  • If it requires a delivery or billing.
  • Whether it’s a service, a configurable product, or a standard material.
  • How it integrates with BOMs or solution components.

Reference Article/Blog explaining Item Categeory & group : Link

In short, the Item Category defines the business logic for the material in transactional documents.

Why Assign Item Category During Sync to SAP CPQ?

When materials are synced from SAP ERP to SAP CPQ, they carry essential attributes like material number, description, and pricing conditions. However, without the correct Item Category, CPQ cannot:

  • Determine if the material is a physical product, service, or text item.
  • Apply correct pricing and tax rules.
  • Generate accurate solution structures for complex configurations.

This impacts the integration when below are created:

  • Sales Orders: Applies for all ERP, S/4 HANA Public & Private Cloud
  • Solution Quotations: S/4 HANA Private Cloud or On-prem versions (Sales, Service & Subscription)
  • Solution Orders: S/4 HANA Public Cloud Edition (Sales, Service & Subscription)

Integration with SAP CPQ for Material Replication

SAP CPQ provides Product RestAPI to update itemcategorygroup for Materials..

Technical Note: Updating Item Category in SAP CPQ

SAP CPQ provides a Product REST API that allows you to update the itemCategory field for products. This is useful when you need to dynamically adjust item categories after initial synchronization or based on business rules.

  • Field: itemCategory
  • Purpose: Stores the ERP item category value or a mapped equivalent.
  • Usage: Can be updated via REST API calls for products in CPQ.

Integration Considerations

The standard SAP CPQ–SAP ERP/S4 HANA integration iFlow currently uses SOAP XML for material synchronization. This means:

  • Item category values from ERP cannot be included in the SOAP payload. (Help Doc)
  • If additional updates are needed post-sync, you can leverage the REST API for CPQ to patch the itemCategory field.

Conclusion:
Assigning the right Item Category during material sync to SAP CPQ is not just a technical step—it’s a business-critical process that ensures seamless integration, accurate pricing, and smooth execution of sales and solution orders.

entry.title: SAP Screen Personas 3.0 SP20: Enhancements to Flavor Management, BDT Support, and Adaptive Flavors
entry.content:
The latest update to SAP Screen Personas 3.0 with Service Pack 20 (SP20) introduces several powerful enhancements designed to make flavor creation, maintenance, and device-specific adaptation easier and more flexible than ever.
Below is a summary of the key improvements and how they benefit administrators, developers, and flavor builders.

1.  Copy a Flavor to Multiple Target Flavors

The former "Copy to Application ID" option has been enhanced and renamed to "Copy to Application ID or Flavor ID".
With this improvement, you can now copy a source flavor to target flavor. You can also you can apply the same source flavor to several target flavors in a single step, making mass flavor updates faster and more efficient.

When screens or transactions share similar layouts, you can reuse an existing flavor instead of starting from scratch.
For example: If you have a Display flavor and want to create a Change flavor, you can copy the Display flavor, adjust the fields that differ, and quickly finalize the Change version. This ensures consistency and significantly reduces development time.

Prerequisites

  • Personas Administrator role is required

  • Target flavors must already exist (either empty or with changes)

  • Source flavor must not contain an adaptive stack

For more details, refer to  Copy a Flavor to a Different Transaction in the documentation.
 
Additional  Options for BDT app flavors

BDT (Business Data Toolset) transactions often share identical detail screens but have different entry screens.
To support these scenarios,  an additional option has been introduced for BDT app flavors where the entry screen changes can be skipped during the copy process.
This allows flavor updates to be applied efficiently without impacting initial-screen behavior.

2. Adaptive Flavors for Custom Industrial Devices

Administrators can now define their own device list for adaptive flavor creation in SAP GUI for HTML and Slipstream Engine.

Until SP19, the device list was static and maintained exclusively by SAP. With SP20, administrators can register custom industrial devices used within their organization and specify attributes such as device width and pixel ratio. These values determine how an adaptive flavor is rendered for that specific device.  The newly added devices will be available to choose from list of devices while creating new adaptive flavors.

Additionally, in Slipstream Engine,the custom device created by the administrator becomes available in the Device Preview list, allowing designers to preview exactly how a flavor will appear on a custom company device.

Benefits

  • Enables greater flexibility in optimizing the user experience for rugged devices, handheld scanners, industrial tablets, and other specialized hardware.

  • Ensures that flavors are responsive and visually optimized for the intended device landscape.

  • Streamlines the design cycle and reduces trial-and-error.

For more information, see Devices.

3. BDT Mode Enabled by Default

With SP20, BDT Mode is now enabled by default, simplifying setup and configuration.

This means there is no need to manually set the ENABLE_BDT_MODE parameter in /PERSONAS/ADMIN when creating flavors for Business Data Toolset (BDT)–enabled transactions, such as Business Partner (BP) screens.

To support legacy flavors created without BDT mode enabled, a new parameter—DISABLE_BDT_MODE—has been introduced.

This ensures that administrators can preserve previous behavior and that legacy BDT flavors continue to function correctly after the SP20 upgrade.

For more information, refer note 2451049

4. Message Toast Support

In SP20 , a new scripting API command has been introduced for displaying non-interactive popup messages in SAP GUI for HTML similar to the "toast message" in SAPUI5.  Scripting API command was available only in slipstream engine with SP19. With this new command, you can now easily implement message toasts for simple scenarios, allowing for streamlined feedback that aligns with SAP Fiori standards. This addition helps enhance user experience by providing subtle, non-disruptive messages in SAP Screen Personas.

Example:  session.utils.showMessageToast("This is a toast message");

How it works

  • Shows a small popup message that disappears after a few seconds.

  • The message stays visible if the user hovers or taps on it.

Conclusion

The SP20 release brings meaningful enhancements that streamline flavor management, improve BDT handling, and provide greater flexibility for device-specific adaptations. Whether you’re managing complex environments or designing mobile-friendly screens, these features help deliver a more efficient and tailored user experience.

SP20 related notes: : https://me.sap.com/notes/3672078 

 

Learn more about SAP Screen Personas
  • Online training. The best way to learn the basics about SAP Screen Personas (Adapt UI for classic applications) is to take our free training course on the learning.sap.com platform: https://learning.sap.com/courses/adapting-the-ui-in-sap-s-4hana-cloud-using-sap-screen-personas
  • Connect with your peers. Every other month, we have a group of customers that gather online to share best practices, demo their flavors, and answer each other’s questions. Experts from the product team also join to explain how to use the latest functionality. If you are interested in joining, you can sign up online to join the SAP Screen Personas practitioner forum. This will add you to the mailing list for the monthly meeting summaries. Please contact “Peter Spielvogel“ or me directly if you want to join the monthly calls.
  • Product documentation. The SAP Screen Personas documentation, provides more clear , comprehensive and the latest information about the product.

Going forward with SAP Screen Personas

  1. If you are on SP18 or earlier, we recommend you upgrade now, ideally going directly to SP20.
  2. If you are not currently using SAP Screen Personas, why not?
    Worried that we won’t support it into the future? Don’t be.      We are supporting SAP Screen Personas functionality through at least 2040.
    Have other concerns about the roadmap for SAP Screen Personas? See if we answer them in our latest roadmap blog post .  
  3. SAP Screen Personas is now available with the Default Installation Stack of SAP S/4HANA 2025, Private Cloud Edition

entry.title: RISE with SAP Methodology: A Practical Guide to Modernizing with Confidence
entry.content:
Part one of the five-part series, “RISE with SAP Methodology.”

Let’s face it: today’s business world doesn’t slow down for anyone.

Markets shift overnight. Customers expect every interaction to feel personal. Supply chains need to be flexible enough to handle the unexpected while running efficiently. But what does that all mean for your company? You already know you need to modernize, simplify, and adapt. But there’s a big gap between knowing you need to change and knowing how to actually make that change happen.

That gap is where progress often stalls and where frustration climbs. For many organizations, that uncertainty—not the technology itself—is what holds transformation back.

The transformation questions you need to ask

If you’re moving from an on-premises environment to the cloud, it can feel a bit like standing at the foot of a mountain. You can see the summit where innovation, speed, and clarity reside, but the path upward isn’t always clear.

Along the way, the same questions tend to pop up:

  • Where do we start?
  • How do we ensure business operations don’t miss a beat?
  • How do we design processes for the future, not just repeat what we’ve always done?
  • How do we get business and IT aligned around a single vision?
  • How do we keep everything on track from strategy to daily execution?

Here’s the truth: transformation needs structure, transparency, and the confidence that every step moves your business forward. Otherwise, even well-intentioned initiatives can lose momentum, drift off course, or grow more complex than they need to be.

RISE with SAP Methodology (aka your guided journey)

At SAP, we’ve seen firsthand the struggles organizations face as they navigate their transformation.

That’s precisely why we created RISE with SAP Methodology. The proven, experience-backed approach guides the entire journey with clarity, consistency, and confidence, bringing together three essential elements, as shown in the figure below:

  • Standardized framework based on a clear structure with phases, quality gates, and a broad range of project experience
  • Integrated chain of tools that fit together throughout the transformation journey
  • Dedicated expert guidance given through a comprehensive, guided service supported by SAP and SAP-qualified partners

Figure: The components of RISE with SAP Methodology

But this methodology is much more than “another best practice.” It’s a reliable path forward.

With RISE with SAP Methodology, your cloud transformation becomes:

  • Structured instead of improvised
  • Transparent instead of uncertain
  • Collaborative instead of isolated
  • Innovation- and outcome-focused instead of task-driven

In other words, you’re modernizing with clarity, not taking on the risk of trial and error.

The real benefit of the methodology

After supporting countless transformations across industries, SAP has consistently seen one pattern emerge: when companies follow a structured, proven approach, results come faster and with far more confidence.

Here’s what our customers have achieved using RISE with SAP Methodology in combination with tools of the toolchain:

  • Up to 30% reduction in transformation costs
  • Up to 35% faster realization of business benefits
  • Up to 70% increase in business agility
  • Up to 40% acceleration in innovation cycles

Numbers like these tell the story better than we ever could. They reflect what becomes possible when organizations have the clarity, alignment, and guardrails needed to transform with purpose.

A great future for your business is within reach

When it comes to your transformation journey as an SAP customer, you’re not going through it alone. Our goal is to support you at every stage with guidance, expertise, and a methodology that’s already proven its value. When you rely on RISE with SAP Methodology, you’re choosing a modern, sustainable, innovation-ready future—built on the clarity and confidence to navigate every step of the journey.

To learn more about RISE with SAP Methodology, read our in-depth overview.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

What’s next?
In the next installment of our “RISE with SAP Methodology” series, we’ll take you deeper into the methodology itself:

December 10: "Deep Dive: Inside the Framework of RISE with SAP Methodology"

Stay tuned for the rest of the blog series, too:

  • January 14: The Integrated Toolchain in a Nutshell
  • January 28: Expert Guidance: Your Guided Transformation Accelerator
  • February 11: The Combined Power of SAP Business AI and RISE with SAP Methodology

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

#clouderpprivate #s4hanacloud #sap #risewithsap #transformation #risewithsapmethodology

entry.title: Key User Custom Fields: Adding or Removing Business Contexts
entry.content:
Have you ever been in a situation where you created a key user custom field (called custom field for the rest of this blog) for one business context, and it turned out that you also needed the identical field for another business context? 

If your answer is yes, then this blog post is just for you. In this blog, we explain which alternatives we offer to propagate a custom field into additional business contexts. Starting with the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 and SAP S/4HANA 2025 releases, it's now possible to propagate an existing custom field to every other business context. In this blog, you’ll learn how to use this new functionality.

How to add a business context to an existing custom field 

From the very beginning, the Custom Fields Fiori app offers two ways to enable an existing custom field for additional business contexts: 

  1. By enabling a business scenario for a custom field, additional business contexts are enabled automatically. The corresponding data flows between these involved business contexts are activated, too. Therefore, custom field data is automatically transferred from one business context to the other in copy processes of the extended applications
  2.  By enabling a standard CDS view for a given key user field that exposes data from several business contexts (this can happen in cases where the CDS view represents a union of different business object nodes) 

So far, so good. But what happens if none of the options above enable you to propagate your existing custom field into your required business context? In this case, you can use our new feature. It allows you to propagate an existing custom field in any arbitrary business context, even if there are no corresponding business scenarios or union CDS views. 

Let’s have a look at how that works. We'll provide a concrete example for the new “Add Business Context” feature: 

Let’s assume you created a custom field “YY1_INVOICE_TYPE” of type code list (with a fixed set of possible code values like “Standard Invoice”, “Partial Invoice”, “Corrected Invoice”, …) for business context “Accounting: Journal Entry Item” (FINS_JOURNAL_ENTRY_ITEM). Afterwards it turned out that you also needed this field for business context “Group Reporting: Journal Entry Item” (FINCS_JOURNAL_ENTRY_ITEM).  
 
As there is no business scenario and no union view available that would allow you to propagate the field into the “FINCS_JOURNAL_ENTRY_ITEM” business context, in the past, the only option would have been to  

  1. create another custom field for business context “FINCS_JOURNAL_ENTRY_ITEM” with a similar name (you can't have the same name twice) and 
  2. define (and later on maintain) the exact same code values for each of the custom fields separately 

With the new “Add Business Context” feature, this is no longer necessary. You simply can add the custom field to the business context “FINCS_JOURNAL_ENTRY_ITEM”. 

In the screenshot below, you can see the custom field “YY1_INVOICETYPE” that's already been created on the business context “FINS_JOURNAL_ENTRY_ITEM”. As soon as you select this field, the “Add Business Context” button on the bottom right corner is clickable. 

Custom Field on business context “FINS_JOURNAL_ENTRY_ITEM” 

As soon as you click “Add Business Context”, the standard business context search help popup is shown allowing you to select an additional business context. Here, you can choose the business context “FINCS_JOURNAL_ENTRY_ITEM”. 

Choosing business context FINCS_JOURNAL_ENTRY_ITEM 

As soon as you choose the business context “FINCS_JOURNAL_ENTRY_ITEM”, the business context is immediately added to the custom field. 

Business context “FINCS_JOURNAL_ENTRY_ITEM” has been added to the custom field 

That’s it. You can now publish the custom field and then you are done. 

Please note that this feature is available starting from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 and SAP S/4HANA 2025. 

This functionality is also available for SAP S/4HANA 2023 with support package 4. For older support packages it's available via deploying SAP note 3567408 – “Change Type of a Custom Field / Add or Remove Business Contexts to a Custom Field”.  

Next, let's take a look at how to remove business contexts from a custom field. 

How to remove a business context from a custom field 

Let’s assume that a couple of days after you enabled business context “FINCS_JOURNAL_ENTRY_ITEM” for custom field “YY1_INVOICETYPE”, it turns out that the situation has changed, and you don't need this business context any longer in this custom field. In the past, there was no way to remove a dedicated business context from a custom field.  

With the new feature, it's now possible to remove a dedicated business context from a given custom field. Within the field list shown in the Custom Fields Fiori app, you mark the entry for the business context you want to remove of custom field “YY1_INVOICETYPE”. As soon as you've done that, the “Delete” button on the bottom right corner of the screen is clickable. Once you click on the down arrow within the “Delete” button, the option “Remove Field from Business Context” appears (see the screenshot below). 

“Remove Field from Business Context” option in the Custom Fields app 

As soon as you click on this option, a popup is shown asking you whether you really want to delete the field from this business context (see the screenshot below).  

Confirmation popup “Do you want to remove selected field from business context” 

Once you click on “Delete”, the selected business context is removed from the field and the publishing process for this change is automatically triggered. 

With this, you are done. You successfully removed the business context “FINCS_JOURNAL_ENTRY_ITEM” from custom field “YY1_INVOICETYPE” 

Custom field successfully removed from business context “FINCS_JOURNAL_ENTRY_ITEM” 

Congratulations! 
Please note that in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Editions, a removal of a business context from a custom field is only possible if the adding of the business context to this custom field has not been released with a software collection so far. Afterwards, you can still delete the entire custom field, but you can no longer choose to only remove the business context you've added. 

This functionality is also available for SAP S/4HANA 2023 with support package 4. For older support packages, it's available via deploying SAP note 3567408 – “Change Type of a Custom Field / Add or Remove Business Contexts to a Custom Field”.  

Please note that this blog has been elaborated by a team of experts. I want to thank Yasmina van Rooij (YasminavanRooij), Christian Fuhlbruegge(ChristianFuhlbruegge),  and Karsten Schaser (Karsten_Schaser) for their extremely helpful contributions. 

Feedback, Comments, or Questions: 

You’re cordially invited to provide feedback, comments, or questions in the comments section below. Please follow our profiles to get updates when we publish more posts on these topics. 
Feel invited to post and answer questions here (https://answers.sap.com/tags/270c4f37-c335-46e1-bfad-a256637d5e26) and read other posts on the topic (https://blogs.sap.com/tags/270c4f37-c335-46e1-bfad-a256637d5e26/). 

Other related blog posts: 

  1. Key User Custom Fields: When to use what type of code list 
  1. SAP S/4HANA Key User Extensibility: Custom field with context-dependent value help 
  1. SAP S/4HANA Key User Extensibility powered by Embedded Steampunk: Custom Field with ABAP implemented Value Help 
  1. Enrich SAP S/4HANA Key User Custom fields with Intent-Based Navigation

entry.title: SAP Tax and Revenue Management - What is new for the S/4HANA 2025 (initial) release
entry.content:
Dear readers,

With the S/4HANA 2025 (initial shipment) OnPrem/Private Cloud release, SAP has delivered several new capabilities in its Tax and Revenue Management solution. In this blog, I provide an overview of these developments and what they mean for TRM users:

Enterprise Search Models for Form Bundles and Contact Objects

You can now use Enterprise Search to quickly locate form bundles and contract objects for any business partner and contract account category combination directly from the SAP Fiori launchpad, using predefined search criteria. The results are presented as a worklist that summarizes the relevant form bundles and contract objects and provides actionable items for drilling down into detailed information.

For more information, see:

Help Document: Enterprise Search for Form Bundles Available

Help Document: Enterprise Search for Public Sector Contract Objects Available

Enterprise Search 

 

Expansion of transparent table form framework

 
We are introducing enhanced functionality for managing TTF scenarios, allowing you to easily add, update, and rename form fields. In addition, you can now manually select the package used to create database tables for ISR Form Scenarios, giving you greater control over your setup

For more information, see: Help Document: Enhancements to TTF Framework 

 

Situation Handling for Form Processing mass program 

Use the situation-handling framework to react during the mass activity for form processing (SAP transaction FMCAPFPF) and to monitor form-bundle mass runs with real-time alerts, enabling earlier detection and intervention.

For more information, see: Help Document: Handling Situations

 

Joule Conversational search for Application Help

 
You can now ask questions in natural language in Joule copilot and have Joule answers based on the available documentation in SAP Help Portal for use in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition
 
For more information, see: Help Document: Joule Conversational Search
 
Stay tuned for more insights in my next post! Until then, thanks for reading, and feel free to share your thoughts or questions in the comments. 

Diego Gaudenzi, Tax and Revenue Management Product Manager

entry.title: SAP HCM Processes and Forms JAVA and Adobe no longer available in SAP S/4HANA
entry.content:
The Readiness Check for migration to S/4HANA reported that the functionality “S4TWL – HCM Processes and Forms JAVA and Adobe” is no longer available in SAP S/4HANA 2022 or higher, but an alternative exists.

​The methodology adopted for the analysis of Bank of Italy’s HR Processes and Forms processes starts from the analysis of note 3224318 - S4TWL – HCM Processes and Forms JAVA, WDA with Adobe - SAP for Me which clarifies that after the activation of SAP HCM for SAP S/4HANA (the H4S4_1 business function), it will no longer be technically possible to use HCM Processes and Forms based on WebDynpro ABAP with Adobe Form technology.

​In S/4HANA, a similar functionality is available with SAP HCM Processes and Forms on Fiori or WebDynpro ABAP (without Adobe).

​New technologies such as Fiori Forms (recommended by SAP) or WDA Forms should therefore be applied.

​You can configure “mass process” with FPM forms instead of Adobe forms (SAP note 3261183 Mass Process with FPM Forms). 

​Future Customer Strategy H4S4 (3006433 - Support for HCM Process & Forms with Adobe forms will be discontinued - SAP for Me  ) :

​- For new process instances:
 a) The process must be configured using Fiori or FPM forms technologies. New process instances will use Fiori or FPM  technologies

b) You can attach PDFs as attachments while executing new process instances

​- For existing process instances:
 It is possible to see Abobe process instances that already exist using the Process browser application. More details in SAP Note 3124740-Support to show PDF forms for Adobe and Fiori Processes using WDA Process browser Application

  • ​For forms based on Fiori technology, customers will see the form download button in the Process Browser application if the PDF form is maintained in the process configuration)
  • Use transaction HRASR_DT - Maintain Print Form in Design Time Tool to activate the form download button.

POSSIBLE S/4HANA MIGRATION PATHS 

​There is no automatic functionality to transform SAP HCM Processes and Forms processes from Adobe Forms scenario to Fiori scenarios or WDA Forms scenarios.

​It will therefore be a "manual" implementation activity

​For HCM Processes and Forms for Fiori you will need to follow the SAP Note configuration guidelines: 2673872

​It is essential to activate the business function HCM_ASR_CI_ 7 using transaction SFW5.
